nexttext: where

is the probability of particle emission. The $N$ is the observed number of particles and  $m$ and $k$ are the two parameters of the NBD.  The operational definition tells us that $m$ is connected with the measured multiplicity, $m = \langle N\rangle$ (at least for $m = const$). The actual meaning of the parameters $m$ and $k$ depends on the particular dynamical description of the measured $P(N)$ resulting in the NBD. Its history begins almost a century ago \cite{Old}. It was then realized that the NBD emerges whenever one has to account for a fluctuating medium \cite{VP}, or for a system which is intrinsically nonextensive \cite{WWq}. It emerges also from the information theory (Shannon entropy) approach \cite{MaxEnt}. In multiparticle production phenomenology the NBD has been obtained in the bag model \cite{MGBM}, in the stochastic bootstrap model \cite{SBM,SBM1}, in numerous descriptions using branching and stochastic processes \cite{MP,SBW,TA} or using a general form of the grand canonical partition function \cite{AM1,AM2,AM3}. It also describes in a natural way different kinds of multiparton interactions \cite{MPI,WDW,DN} and the production of some specific initial gluonic states in the first phase of the interaction process, the so called "glittering glasmas" \cite{GLMc}. For the purpose of this work we shall concentrate on the very popular and frequently used clan model (CM) \cite{GU,CM,CMa1,CMa2,CMb1,CMb2,CM1} (for its more theoretical justification see \cite{CMTh,CMTh1,CMTh2,AB}) and, on the not so widely known  cascade-stochastic model \cite{CSF,CSF1}.

The multiplicity distribution (MD) can be defined in different ways. For our further consideration the most suitable are the recurrence relations between some selected distributions. The simplest one is the relation between adjacent distributions, $P(N)$ and $P(N+1)$, only. It corresponds to the assumption of a connection existing only between the production of $N$ and $N + 1$ particles:
prevtext: where

nexttext: The type of MD described by it is determined by the function $g(N)$. The simplest nontrivial choice is given by a linear relation on multiplicity $N$,
prevtext:
is the probability of particle emission. The $N$ is the observed number of particles and  $m$ and $k$ are the two parameters of the NBD.  The operational definition tells us that $m$ is connected with the measured multiplicity, $m = \langle N\rangle$ (at least for $m = const$). The actual meaning of the parameters $m$ and $k$ depends on the particular dynamical description of the measured $P(N)$ resulting in the NBD. Its history begins almost a century ago \cite{Old}. It was then realized that the NBD emerges whenever one has to account for a fluctuating medium \cite{VP}, or for a system which is intrinsically nonextensive \cite{WWq}. It emerges also from the information theory (Shannon entropy) approach \cite{MaxEnt}. In multiparticle production phenomenology the NBD has been obtained in the bag model \cite{MGBM}, in the stochastic bootstrap model \cite{SBM,SBM1}, in numerous descriptions using branching and stochastic processes \cite{MP,SBW,TA} or using a general form of the grand canonical partition function \cite{AM1,AM2,AM3}. It also describes in a natural way different kinds of multiparton interactions \cite{MPI,WDW,DN} and the production of some specific initial gluonic states in the first phase of the interaction process, the so called "glittering glasmas" \cite{GLMc}. For the purpose of this work we shall concentrate on the very popular and frequently used clan model (CM) \cite{GU,CM,CMa1,CMa2,CMb1,CMb2,CM1} (for its more theoretical justification see \cite{CMTh,CMTh1,CMTh2,AB}) and, on the not so widely known  cascade-stochastic model \cite{CSF,CSF1}.

The multiplicity distribution (MD) can be defined in different ways. For our further consideration the most suitable are the recurrence relations between some selected distributions. The simplest one is the relation between adjacent distributions, $P(N)$ and $P(N+1)$, only. It corresponds to the assumption of a connection existing only between the production of $N$ and $N + 1$ particles:

nexttext:
It covers, for example, the Poissonian distribution (for $ \alpha = \langle N\rangle$ and $\beta =0$), binomial distribution (for $\alpha = \langle N\rangle k/(k -\langle N\rangle)$ and $\beta = a/k$) and NBD (for $\alpha = \langle N\rangle k/(k +\langle N\rangle)$ and $ \beta = a/k$). Usually, when searching for the best MD to fit the experimental data, one modifies accordingly the function $g(N)$ (for example, by introducing higher order terms \cite{HC} or by using its more involved form\emph{\emph{}}s \cite{MF,Z1}).

The more general form of recurrence relation connects the multiplicity $N+1$ with all smaller multiplicities and has the form \cite{ST}:
prevtext: The type of MD described by it is determined by the function $g(N)$. The simplest nontrivial choice is given by a linear relation on multiplicity $N$,

It covers, for example, the Poissonian distribution (for $ \alpha = \langle N\rangle$ and $\beta =0$), binomial distribution (for $\alpha = \langle N\rangle k/(k -\langle N\rangle)$ and $\beta = a/k$) and NBD (for $\alpha = \langle N\rangle k/(k +\langle N\rangle)$ and $ \beta = a/k$). Usually, when searching for the best MD to fit the experimental data, one modifies accordingly the function $g(N)$ (for example, by introducing higher order terms \cite{HC} or by using its more involved form\emph{\emph{}}s \cite{MF,Z1}).

The more general form of recurrence relation connects the multiplicity $N+1$ with all smaller multiplicities and has the form \cite{ST}:

(\ref{NBD}) because only the probability of particle emission $p$ is affected, cf. Eq. (\ref{partem}). Changes in the parameter $k$ would result in changing the form of the original NBD.},

The black squares denote the $CMS/DCM$ ratio calculated using  $ a = 0.0455$, $b = 11$ and $c = 20.252$. More careful examination shows that introducing additionally a small nonlinearity in the number of clusters, for example taking
prevtext: This corresponds to a rather complicated, nonlinear and non monotonic form of $g(N)$ given by Eq.(\ref{g(N)}), with parameter $\alpha$ equal to

nexttext:
with $a_1 = 0.044$, $b = 11$, $ c = 20.252$ and $a_2 = 1.04\cdot 10^{-9}$, improves further the agreement with data.

Both proposed dependencies of $m$ on $N$ (cf. Eqs. (\ref{NcN1}) and (\ref{Non})) are shown in Fig. \ref{Fig_Modification}. Fig. \ref{Fig_Mod_Nc} shows the corresponding  multiplicity dependence of the number of clans in the DCM scenario, $N_C(N)$ (cf. Eq. (\ref{NcN}), the value of parametr $k$ used here is $k=1.45$), compared with the flat dependence observed for the NBD (with $m = 25.5$ and $ k = 1.45$). In both cases the non-monotonic form of the proposed modification mentioned above is clearly visible. It is located in the region of small multiplicities $N$. After it both $m(N)$ and $N_C(N)$ grow steadily.  As already mentioned, this is the price to keep a single MD and to obtain the desired flat ratio shown in Fig. \ref{Fig_Modified} over the whole region of multiplicities $N$ measured. At this moment we cannot offer any plausible interpretation of such behavior\footnote{Note that the spout-like form of the modification used here is just the simplest possible choice of parametrization that brings agreement with data.}.

Continuing our presentation we show in Fig. \ref{Fig_Mod_nc} the multiplicity in a single clan,

nexttext: i.e., the probability of emission ratio $p(N)$ is given by the logistic function,

The non-monoticity mentioned before is very pronounced in the $p(N)$ shown in Fig. \ref{Fig_PPE}. This fact will be crucial in our further discussion.


To close this Section note that whereas in the standard NBD the mean number of clans, $\langle N_C\rangle$, is assumed to be constant, in reality it fluctuates from event to event (in a poissonian way). Because multiplicity $N$ is correlated with $N_C$ it means that, by allowing for $N$-dependent $\langle N_C\rangle$, we simply introduce stronger correlations between these quantities than those present in the usual NBD. The other remark worth remembering is that in the production processes the important variable is the energy $W$ allowed for the production of particles\footnote{The fraction $W/\sqrt{s}$ is known as the \emph{inelasticity} and was widely used some time ago, cf. \cite{inel,inel1}. Recently it was rediscovered and used again under the new name \emph{effective energy} \cite{EE}.}. Assuming now that multiplicity $N$ depends logarithmically on $W$ \cite{PPP},
prevtext: i.e., the probability of emission ratio $p(N)$ is given by the logistic function,

prevtext: In fact, the above result is valid for any distribution $P(M)$ with probability generating function $G_M(s)$, i.e., the term with $N=0$,
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E26.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="g(0)=\frac{\alpha}{1-\alpha+\alpha G_{M}(0)}\frac{dG_{M}(s)}{ds}\Bigg{|}_{s=0}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mi>α</mi><mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>G</mi><mi>M</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>G</mi><mi>M</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo fence="true" maxsize="260%" minsize="260%">|</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>
